sec.title: Scaling laws for internal and interaction energies
sec.p: Here, we provide a physical interpretation of the internal free energy ωi\begin{document}$\omega_{i}$\end{document}. For simplicity, we consider a homogeneous system solely composed of assemblies of size i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}, characterised by the volume fraction vector ϕ(i)\begin{document}$\phi^{(i)}$\end{document}, with ϕi(i)=1\begin{document}$\phi^{(i)}_{i}=1$\end{document} and ϕj(i)=0\begin{document}$\phi^{(i)}_{j}=0$\end{document} for i≠j\begin{document}$i\neq j$\end{document}. Making use of Equation 1, the internal free energy of such systems can be written as(19)ωi=f(ϕ(i))ν1−kBTi−1ln⁡i−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \omega_i = f(\phi^{(i)}) \nu_1 - k_\text{B} T \; i^{-1} \ln i^{-1} ,$$\end{document}

with f(ϕ(i))ν1\begin{document}$f(\phi^{(i)})\nu_{1}$\end{document} being the free energy associated with each monomer belonging to the i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}-th assembly. The second term in the equation above is the conformational entropy that stems from having more accessible states with increasing assembly size. Thus, Equation 19 allows interpreting ωi\begin{document}$\omega_{i}$\end{document} as the free energy of monomers inside an assembly of size i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}, coming only from bonds between monomers. To quantify it, we introduce the number of binding sites for each monomer, z\begin{document}$z$\end{document}. Following Israelachvili, 2015, we distinguish between nb\begin{document}$n_{\text{b}}$\end{document} monomers at the boundaries of the assembly, and (i−nb)\begin{document}$(i-n_{\text{b}})$\end{document} in the assembly bulk. Monomers in the bulk can saturate all their z\begin{document}$z$\end{document} binding sites, while, in general, monomers at the boundaries are able to saturate only zb<z\begin{document}$z_{\text{b}} \lt z$\end{document}. Thus, we get(20)ωi=z(i−nb)+zbnb2iΔω=z2Δω−(z−zb)nb2iΔω,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} \omega_i &= \frac{z (i - n_\text{b}) + z_\text{b} n_\text{b} }{2 i} \, \Delta \omega \\&= \frac{z }{2} \, \Delta \omega- (z-z_\text{b})\frac{n_\text{b} }{2 i} \, \Delta \omega ,\end{array}$$\end{document}

where Δω\begin{document}$\Delta\omega$\end{document} is the free energy associated with the formation of a single bond, that is composed of an energetic and an entropic part. The factor two avoids double-counting.

We describe three species of assemblies: linear, disc-like, and three-dimensional. These can be realised by varying the number of binding sites and their orientation (Nandi et al., 2022). Linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) are defined to have only two binding sites. They can be pictured as one-dimensional semi-flexible assemblies with no loops, leading to nb=2\begin{document}$n_{\text{b}}=2$\end{document}, z=2\begin{document}$z=2$\end{document} and zb=1\begin{document}$z_{\text{b}}=1$\end{document}. Planar assemblies (d=2\begin{document}$d=2$\end{document}) are defined to have z>2\begin{document}$z \gt 2$\end{document} co-planar binding sites, for which nb≃i\begin{document}$n_{\text{b}}\simeq\sqrt{i}$\end{document}. Three-dimensional assemblies (d=3\begin{document}$d=3$\end{document}) are characterised by z>2\begin{document}$z \gt 2$\end{document} binding sites with no precise orientation leading to nb≃i23\begin{document}$n_{\text{b}}\simeq i^{\frac{2}{3}}$\end{document}. Summing up, we get(21)nb≃id−1d,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle n_\text{b} \simeq i^\frac{d-1}{d},$$\end{document}

that inserted in Equation 20, decomposing Δω\begin{document}$\Delta\omega$\end{document} in its energetic and entropic contribution, gives(22)ωi=α(eint−Tsint)−(eint−Tsinti1/d),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \omega_i = \alpha\left(e_\text{int} - T s_\text{int} \right) - \left(\frac{e_\text{int} - T s_\text{int}}{i^{1/d}}\right) ,$$\end{document}

where α is a constant that depends on number and geometry of the binding sites. Identifying ω∞=α(eint−Tsint)\begin{document}$\omega_{\infty}=\alpha\left(e_{\text{int}}-Ts_{\text{int}}\right)$\end{document}, Equation 22 leads to Equation 8, in the main text. The constant terms ω∞\begin{document}$\omega_{\infty}$\end{document}, does not affect chemical nor phase equilibrium. However, in the case of d=2,3\begin{document}$d=2,3$\end{document} and M→∞\begin{document}$M\to\infty$\end{document}, ω∞\begin{document}$\omega_{\infty}$\end{document} it becomes important to study the gelation of the protein-rich phase, see Appendix 4. In Equation 8, the second term represents a boundary interaction penalty, accounting for the fact that monomers at the assembly boundary can realise fewer internal bonds than monomers at the assembly bulk, in analogy with the physical origin of surface tension.

We now discuss the size dependence of the interaction parameters χij\begin{document}$\chi_{ij}$\end{document}. Starting from a lattice model, these parameters can be expressed in terms of the energetic parameters eij\begin{document}$e_{ij}$\end{document} corresponding to having two neighbouring monomers belonging to i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} and j\begin{document}$j$\end{document}. In particular, χij=2eij−eii−ejj\begin{document}$\chi_{ij}=2e_{ij}-e_{ii}-e_{jj}$\end{document}. Assuming that the energies associated with monomer-monomer interactions do not vary within assemblies, i.e., eij=e11\begin{document}$e_{ij}=e_{11}$\end{document} is constant, we get χij=0\begin{document}$\chi_{ij}=0$\end{document}. Moreover, we now discuss the scaling of χis=2eis−eii−ess\begin{document}$\chi_{i\text{s}}=2e_{i\text{s}}-e_{ii}-e_{\text{ss}}$\end{document}. If the monomer-solvent interactions are also chosen to be size-independent, i.e., eis=e1s\begin{document}$e_{i\text{s}}=e_{1\text{s}}$\end{document}, we get χis=2e1s−e11−ess=χ\begin{document}$\chi_{i\text{s}}=2e_{1\text{s}}-e_{11}-e_{\text{ss}}=\chi$\end{document}. This explains the scaling in Class 1 (see Equation 9).

However, many proteins of interest screen their hydrophobic interaction when forming assemblies (Hughes et al., 2018; Luo et al., 2018; Seim et al., 2022), implying that the interactions between monomers in assembly i with solvent (s) eis\begin{document}$e_{i {\rm s}}$\end{document} varies with assembly size i. In each assembly, this energy per monomer comes from two contributions. The first corresponds to monomers in the bulk which are (n−nb)\begin{document}$(n-n_{\rm b})$\end{document} and have interaction with solvent e1s′\begin{document}$e'_{1{\rm s}}$\end{document}. The second one corresponds to the nb\begin{document}$n_{\rm b}$\end{document} monomers at the assembly boundary, characterised by interaction with solvent e1s\begin{document}$e_{1{\rm s}}$\end{document}. We get(23)eis=e1s′(i−nb)+e1snbi.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle e_{i\text{s}} = \frac{e_{1\text{s}}' (i - n_\text{b}) + e_{1\text{s}} n_\text{b} }{i} .$$\end{document}

Using the scaling of nb/i\begin{document}$n_{\text{b}}/i$\end{document} already introduced above in the discussion of the internal free energy scaling, Equation 21, we obtain Equation 10. By abbreviating χis′=2e1s′−e11−ess=χ′\begin{document}$\chi_{i\text{s}}^{\prime}=2e_{1\text{s}}^{\prime}-e_{11}-e_{\text{ss}}=\chi^{\prime}$\end{document}; this case corresponds to Class 2.

sec.title: Linear assemblies belonging to class 1
sec.p: For class 1 and d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}, Equation 4 reads(24)ϕi=i(ϕ1ϕ~)iϕ~,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \phi_i = i \, \left(\frac{\phi_1}{\tilde{\phi}} \right) ^{i} \, \tilde{\phi},$$\end{document}

where we have introduced the characteristic volume fraction(25)ϕ~=exp⁡(eint−sintTkBT−1).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde{\phi} = \exp \left(\frac{e_\text{int} - s_\text{int} T}{k_\text{B} T}-1 \right).$$\end{document}

It is straightforward to verify that the latter volume fraction is proportional to the assembly threshold defined in Equation 11 i.e., ϕ~=e/(1−e)2ϕ∗∼ϕ∗\begin{document}$\tilde{\phi}=\text{e}/(1-\text{e})^{2}\phi^{*}\sim\phi^{*}$\end{document}.

caption.title: A volume fraction threshold separates two assembly regimes in homogeneous systems.
caption.p: (a) Illustration of assemblies belonging to Class 1 with different spatial dimensions. (b) Assembly size distribution at low total macromolecular volume fraction: ϕtot=0.2ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}=0.2\phi^{*}$\end{document}. Disregarding assembly dimension, d, the macromolecules are mainly in the monomer state, i.e., ϕ1≃ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}. (c) For ϕtot=10ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}=10\phi^{*}$\end{document}, the monomer volume fraction saturates at ϕ1≃ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi^{*}$\end{document} and big assemblies begin to populate the system. For linear assemblies (corresponding to d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document} in Equation 8), the distribution becomes peaked at an intermediate value imax>1\begin{document}$i_{\text{max}} \gt 1$\end{document} and then exponentially cut off. For planar and three-dimensional assemblies, d=2,3\begin{document}$d=2,3$\end{document} , the distribution becomes bimodal, with peaks at i=1\begin{document}$i=1$\end{document} and i=M\begin{document}$i=M$\end{document}, the maximum assembly size (M=50\begin{document}$M=50$\end{document}). This bimodal behaviour hints at the emergence of a gelation transition in the limit M→∞\begin{document}$M\to\infty$\end{document}. In the insets, we show the scaling of concentrations ci=ϕi/νi\begin{document}$c_{i}=\phi_{i}/\nu_{i}$\end{document} with assembly size. For d=2,3\begin{document}$d=2,3$\end{document}, and above the ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi^{*}$\end{document} threshold, deviations from the classical exponential decay are present. Here eint/χ=−1\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=-1$\end{document}, sint/kB=−1\begin{document}$s_{\text{int}}/k_{\text{B}}=-1$\end{document}, M=50\begin{document}$M=50$\end{document}, T/T0=0.25\begin{document}$T/T_{0}=0.25$\end{document}.

sec.p: In Appendix 3—figure 1, we show the assembly size distribution in homogeneous mixtures obtained by numerically solving Equation 4 together with Equation 5, with a cut-off M=50\begin{document}$M=50$\end{document}. We characterise the behaviour of assemblies with different spatial dimensions d=1,2,3\begin{document}$d=1,2,3$\end{document}, see Appendix 3—figure 1a. For dilute solutions, corresponding to ϕtot≪ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}\ll\phi^{*}$\end{document}, the size distribution is dominated by monomers while larger assemblies have vanishing volume fraction, i.e., ϕ1≃ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}, see Appendix 3—figure 1b. For ϕtot≫ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}\gg\phi^{*}$\end{document}, the monomer volume fraction saturates at ϕ1≃ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi^{*}$\end{document} and assemblies begin to populate the system. As depicted in Appendix 3—figure 1b, above this threshold, the size distribution depends crucially on assembly dimension d\begin{document}$d$\end{document}. For linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document} in Equation 8), the distribution becomes peaked at a value M>1\begin{document}$M \gt 1$\end{document} and then exponentially decays. For planar and three-dimensional assemblies, d=2,3\begin{document}$d=2,3$\end{document} in Equation 8, the distribution becomes bimodal peaked at i=1\begin{document}$i=1$\end{document} and i=M\begin{document}$i=M$\end{document}, the maximum assembly size (M=50\begin{document}$M=50$\end{document} in Appendix 3—figure 1c). The behaviour of the system at high density can be quantitatively studied by performing the thermodynamic limit, i.e., M→∞\begin{document}$M\to\infty$\end{document}. Within this limit, the series defined in the conservation law, Equation 5 can be explicitly solved, leading to(26)ϕ1ϕ~=1+2ϕtotϕ~−1+4ϕtotϕ~2ϕtotϕ~.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\phi_1}{\tilde{\phi}} = \frac{ 1+2 \frac{\phi_\text{tot} }{\tilde{\phi}} - \sqrt{1+4 \frac{\phi_\text{tot} }{\tilde{\phi}}} } { 2\frac{\phi_\text{tot} }{\tilde{\phi}} } .$$\end{document}

Recalling that ϕ~=e/(1−e)2ϕ∗\begin{document}$\tilde{\phi}=\text{e}/(1-\text{e})^{2}\phi^{*}$\end{document}, this leads to ϕ1≃ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}, in the regime ϕtot≪ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}\ll\phi^{*}$\end{document}, while for ϕtot≫ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}\gg\phi^{*}$\end{document}, we get ϕ1≃ϕ∗\begin{document}$\phi_{1}\simeq\phi^{*}$\end{document}.

The maximum of the volume fraction distribution in Equation 24 can be obtained imposing ∂iϕi=0\begin{document}$\partial_{i}{\phi_{i}}=0$\end{document}, leading to(27)imax=1ln⁡(ϕ~/ϕ1)≃ϕtotϕ~.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i_\text{max} = \frac{1}{\ln{(\tilde{\phi}/\phi_1)}} \simeq \sqrt{\frac{\phi_\text{tot}}{\tilde{\phi}}} .$$\end{document}
The approximate expression on the right hand is obtained using Equation 26 and expanding for ϕtot/ϕ~≫1\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}/\tilde{\phi}\gg 1$\end{document}.

The average ⟨i⟩=∑iϕi/∑ϕi\begin{document}$\langle i\rangle=\sum i\phi_{i}/\sum{\phi_{i}}$\end{document} is given by(28)⟨i⟩=ϕ1ϕtot3−ϕ1/ϕ~(1−ϕ1/ϕ~)3≃2imax,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \langle i\rangle = \frac{\phi_1}{\phi_\text{tot}} \frac{3- \phi_1/\tilde{\phi}}{(1- \phi_1/\tilde{\phi})^3} \simeq 2 \, i_\text{max} ,$$\end{document}
where we expanded for ϕtot/ϕ~≫1\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}/\tilde{\phi}\gg 1$\end{document} to obtain the approximate expression.

We can also derive an explicit expression for the free energy as a function of the conserved quantity ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}. This is achieved by plugging ϕi\begin{document}$\phi_{i}$\end{document} given in Equation 24 into Equation 1 Omitting linear terms, which do not influence phase equilibrium, we get(29)fsol=kBTν1[(1−ϕtot)ln⁡(1−ϕtot)+ϕtotln⁡ϕ1ϕ~−ϕ11−ϕ1/ϕ~+χkBTϕtot(1−ϕtot)],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}f_\text{sol} =\frac{k_\text{B} T}{\nu_1} &\left[ (1-\phi_\text{tot}) \ln (1-\phi_\text{tot}) + \phi_\text{tot} \ln\frac{\phi_1}{\tilde{\phi}} \right. \nonumber \\ & \left. - \frac{\phi_1}{1-\phi_1/\tilde{\phi}} + \frac{\chi}{k_\text{B} T} \phi_\text{tot}(1-\phi_\text{tot}) \right]\,, \end{array}$$\end{document}
where the dependence of ϕ1\begin{document}$\phi_{1}$\end{document} on ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} is expressed in Equation 26.

sec.title: Gelation transition for two- and three-dimensional assemblies

caption.title: Gel-sol free energies.
caption.p: (a) The coloured curve indicates the binodal obtained with the Maxwell construction for f=fsol+fgel\begin{document}$f=f_{\text{sol}}+f_{\text{gel}}$\end{document}, together with the estimate ϕsg(T)\begin{document}$\phi^{\text{sg}}(T)$\end{document} (black line, defined in Equation 31) for the transition between homogeneous and gel states. The black cross ‘x’ indicates the triple point. (c-e) Maxwell construction for three different temperature values, the coloured and black, dashed curves represent convex and concave branches of f\begin{document}$f$\end{document}, respectively. Parameters are the same as those in Figure 3; see Appendix 1—table 1.

sec.p: As outlined in Appendix 3—figure 1, for d=2,3\begin{document}$d=2,3$\end{document}, at high ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} for M\begin{document}$M$\end{document} finite, the size distribution shows a bimodal behaviour. This suggests a limit M→∞\begin{document}$M\to\infty$\end{document} that the system undergoes a gelation transition, which is defined as the emergence of an assembly that is comparable with the system size (Tanaka, 2011; Israelachvili, 2015; Deviri and Safran, 2020). To estimate the ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} value at which the transition occurs, we recall Equation 4 and consider the series(30)∑i=1∞ϕi=∑i=1∞i(ϕ1ϕ~)iexp⁡(ΔωkBTid−1d−1).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \phi_i = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} i \left(\frac{\phi_1}{\tilde{\phi}} \right) ^{i} \, \exp \left(\frac{\Delta \omega}{k_\text{B} T} \, i^{\frac{d-1}{d} } -1 \right).$$\end{document}

We note that when N→∞\begin{document}$N\to\infty$\end{document}, this series converges only if ϕ1/ϕ~≤1\begin{document}$\phi_{1}/\tilde{\phi}\leq 1$\end{document}. Thus, we get an upper bound for the series, namely(31)∑i=1∞ϕi≤∑i=1∞iexp⁡(ΔωkBTid−1d−1)≡ϕsg.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \phi_i \leq \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} i \,\exp \left(\frac{\Delta \omega}{k_\text{B} T} \, i^{\frac{d-1}{d} } -1 \right) \equiv \phi^\text{sg} .$$\end{document}

Approximating the series with the integral, we get an estimation for ϕsg\begin{document}$\phi^{\text{sg}}$\end{document}:(32)ϕsg={2(6−6Δω+3Δω2−Δω3)Δω4ϕ~,d=2,−32Δω3(2−2Δω+Δω2)ϕ~,d=3.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \phi^\text{sg}=\begin{cases}2\frac{ \left(6- 6\Delta \omega + 3\Delta \omega^2- \Delta \omega^3\right)}{\Delta \omega^4} \tilde{\phi}\, , \qquad &d=2\, ,\\-\frac{3}{2}\frac{\Delta \omega^3} {\left(2- 2\Delta \omega + \Delta \omega^2\right)} \tilde{\phi}\, , \qquad &d=3 \, .\end{cases} $$\end{document}

By the Maxwell construction, Equation 7a, Equation 7b with the free energy Equation 12, we can study the interplay between the gelation transition and phase separation. Here, the parameter ω∞\begin{document}$\omega_{\infty}$\end{document} plays a crucial role. As discussed in Appendix 2, ω∞\begin{document}$\omega_{\infty}$\end{document} contains an energetic and an entropic part and is proportional to eint−Tsint\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}-Ts_{\text{int}}$\end{document}, the coefficient depending on assembly dimension, and number and geometry of the binding sites. Here, for simplicity, we set(33)ω∞=12(eint−Tsint).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \omega_\infty = \frac 1 2 \left(e_\text{int} - T s_\text{int} \right).$$\end{document}

In Appendix 4—figure 1a, we display the result of the construction (coloured curve), where the colour code depicts the monomer fraction ϕ1/ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{1}/\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} in the coexisting phases. Note that the branch of the binodal between the triple point (indicated with a cross) and ϕtot=1\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}=1$\end{document}, has the same trend as the curve that stems from the estimate ϕsg\begin{document}$\phi^{\text{sg}}$\end{document} introduced in Equation 32 (black curve). This is expected since both curves correspond to the boundary between homogeneous mixtures and the gel state.

We also display the free energy for three temperature values corresponding to sol-gel coexistence (Appendix 4—figure 1b), sol-sol and sol-gel coexistence (Appendix 4—figure 1c), and sol-sol coexistence only (Appendix 4—figure 1d). The dashed lines represent values where f\begin{document}$f$\end{document} is not convex. Notice that, for consistency, we use values of fsol\begin{document}$f_{\text{sol}}$\end{document} only up to ϕsg\begin{document}$\phi^{\text{sg}}$\end{document} (denoted by a vertical black line). This is because, as depicted in Appendix 3—figure 1, after this value, a peak at M\begin{document}$M$\end{document}, the finite cut-off used for the numerics, will appear.

sec.title: Mutual feedback between phase separation and assembly equilibria

caption.title: The influence of assemblies on the system phase behaviour.
caption.p: (a) Focusing on systems with d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document} belonging to class 1, we compare three binodals corresponding to assembly strength eint/χ=0.5,−1,−2\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=0.5,-1,-2$\end{document} (coloured curves) and the reference binary mixture composed of monomers and solvent only (black curve). The latter can be associated with the limit eint/χ→∞\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi\to\infty$\end{document}. The region enclosed by the binodal, corresponding to phase separation, expands even for assemblies with no assembly energy eint/χ=0\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=0$\end{document}. This can be explained by the entropic advantage caused by size polydispersity. (b) Dependence of the critical volume fraction and critical temperature on the assembly strength eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}. The presence of assemblies causes Tc\begin{document}$T^{c}$\end{document} and ϕc\begin{document}$\phi^{c}$\end{document} to deviate from the reference values (black dashed lines) corresponding to a binary mixture with monomers and solvent only (eint/χ→∞\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi\to\infty$\end{document}). In particular, for Class 1, making assemblies more energetically favourable, i.e., decreasing eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}, induces an increase in Tc\begin{document}$T^{c}$\end{document} and a decrease in ϕc\begin{document}$\phi^{c}$\end{document}, in turn making phase separation more accessible. Here sint/kB=−2\begin{document}$s_{\text{int}}/k_{\text{B}}=-2$\end{document}, M=∞\begin{document}$M=\infty$\end{document}. (c) Comparison between three binodal lines corresponding to systems belonging to class 2 and d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}, with assembly energies eint/χ=0,−0.5,−1\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=0,-0.5,-1$\end{document} (coloured curves) and the reference binary mixture composed of monomers and solvent only (black curve). (d) For Class 2, decreasing eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}, causes Tc\begin{document}$T^{c}$\end{document} and ϕc\begin{document}$\phi^{c}$\end{document} to decrease, overall hindering phase separation. This is caused by the interaction propensity screening in monomers at the bulk of assemblies belonging to class 2; see Equation 10. Here sint/kB=−2\begin{document}$s_{\text{int}}/k_{\text{B}}=-2$\end{document}, M=∞\begin{document}$M=\infty$\end{document}

sec.p: We first discuss how assemblies can shape the phase diagram. For linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) belonging to Class 1, assemblies facilitate phase separation. Indeed, as illustrated in Appendix 5—figure 1a-b, increasing the relative assembly strength, i.e., decreasing eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}, leads to an upshift in critical temperature and a downshift in critical volume fraction. This trend can be explained by considering that assembly formation, even if energetically disfavoured, reduces the mixing entropy (see the first term in Equation 1). In Appendix 5—figure 1a, we show the binodal lines corresponding to three representative values of the assembly strength: eint/χ=0,−1,−2\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=0,-1,-2$\end{document}. We compare them to the black curve, which corresponds to a binary mixture made of monomers and solvent only (black curve). This reference case can be thought of as the limiting case in which assemblies have an infinite energy penalty, i.e, eint/χ=→∞\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=\to\infty$\end{document}. In Appendix 5—figure 1b, we quantify the changes in critical temperature and critical volume fraction as a function of the relative assembly strength eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}. In Appendix 5—figure 1c-d, we illustrate the behaviour of linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) belonging to Class 2. In contrast to Class 2, assemblies can suppress phase separation. Indeed, making assemblies more favourable by decreasing eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}, the critical temperature decreases, and even if the critical density decreases and the binodal shrinks, see Appendix 5—figure 1c. In Appendix 5—figure 1d, we display critical temperatures and critical volume fraction variations as a function of the relative assembly strength eint/χ\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi$\end{document}.

caption.title: The influence of phase separation on assembly size.
caption.p: (a) Comparison between the size distribution in a homogeneous system and in the corresponding phase-separated system (averaged in both compartments). Here, we consider linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}), M→∞\begin{document}$M\to\infty$\end{document}, ϕtot=0.016\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}=0.016$\end{document}, and T/T0=0.2\begin{document}$T/T_{0}=0.2$\end{document}. We note that the presence of compartments can favour assembly formation, even when the corresponding homogeneous mixture is populated mainly by monomers. The difference in distributions can be quantified utilizing the functional distance, defined in Equation 35. (b) The magnitude of this distance depends on the droplet size and the temperature chosen. The volume corresponding to the maximum distribution distance shifts towards lower values with decreasing temperature T/T0\begin{document}$T/T_{0}$\end{document}. The distributions separated by the maximum distance, for T/T0=0.2\begin{document}$T/T_{0}=0.2$\end{document}, are the ones displayed in a. eint/χ=−0.5\begin{document}$e_{\text{int}}/\chi=-0.5$\end{document}, sint/kB=−2\begin{document}$s_{\text{int}}/k_{\text{B}}=-2$\end{document}, T/T0=0.25\begin{document}$T/T_{0}=0.25$\end{document}.

sec.p: Appendix 5—figure 1 clearly shows that the presence of assemblies affects the phase equilibrium of a mixture. We now prove that, in turn, the total number of assemblies can differ between phase-separating and homogeneous systems with the same total protein volume fraction. To show this, we fix the interaction propensity χ\begin{document}$\chi$\end{document}, the temperature T/T0\begin{document}$T/T_{0}$\end{document}, and the total macromolecule volume fraction ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} to values corresponding to two-phase coexistence at thermodynamic equilibrium. We then compare the assembly size distribution (after averaging over both phases) with the distribution in the corresponding homogeneous state, with the same values of T\begin{document}$T$\end{document} and ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}. Recalling that due to our choice of interaction propensity scaling in Equation 9, the size distribution in the homogeneous system, Equation 4, does not depend on χ\begin{document}$\chi$\end{document}. For this reason, the homogeneous state can be thought of as an unstable state corresponding to the same χ\begin{document}$\chi$\end{document} as the phase separating one, which has not reached phase equilibrium yet, but also as the equilibrium state of a system with the same parameters as the phase separating one, but formed by assemblies that do not interact with the solvent (χ=0\begin{document}$\chi=0$\end{document}).

In Appendix 5—figure 2a, we display results for linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) with T/T0=0.2\begin{document}$T/T_{0}=0.2$\end{document}, and ϕtot=0.016\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}=0.016$\end{document}. We compare the size distribution in the homogeneous system ϕih\begin{document}$\phi^{\text{h}}_{i}$\end{document}, with the weighted average over compartments, defined as(34)ϕ¯i=VIVϕiI+VIIVϕiII,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \bar{\phi}_i = \frac{V^{\rm I}}{V} \phi_i^{\rm I} + \frac{V^{\rm II}}{V} \phi_i^{\rm II} ,$$\end{document}

in the corresponding phase-separated system. Clearly, the two distributions differ, showing that the presence of compartments can lead to larger assemblies. The difference in size distributions can be quantified utilizing the so-called total variation distance, defined as(35)δ(h,g)=supi|hi∑ihi−gi∑igi|.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta(h, g) = \sup_{i} \left| \frac{ h_i }{ \sum_i h_i } - \frac{ g_i }{ \sum_i g_i } \right| .$$\end{document}

This quantity characterizes the distance between two normalised functions as the largest possible distance among values that they assign to the same argument. The distance between the homogeneous size distribution and the distribution defined in Equation 34 depends on the temperature T\begin{document}$T$\end{document} and the total volume fraction ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}, which in turn determines the droplet size. In Appendix 5—figure 2b, we display distribution distances δ(ϕh,ϕ¯)\begin{document}$\delta(\phi^{\text{h}},\bar{\phi})$\end{document} corresponding to different temperatures and droplet volumes. In the limits VI/V→0\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}/V\to 0$\end{document} and VI/V→1\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}/V\to 1$\end{document}, the system becomes homogeneous. As a result, the distribution distance δ(ϕh,ϕ¯)\begin{document}$\delta(\phi^{\text{h}},\bar{\phi})$\end{document} vanishes. Note that the volume corresponding to the maximum distribution distance shifts towards lower values.

sec.title: A Assembly kinetics in homogeneous mixtures
sec.p: In this section, we give the details on the kinetic theory for assembly in non-dilute homogeneous systems that can relax toward chemical equilibrium. Each component i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} follows(36)dϕidt=ri.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d{\phi_{i}}}{dt} =r_{i}.$$\end{document}

The assembly rates ri\begin{document}$r_{i}$\end{document} read(37)ri=i12∑j+k=iΔrjk−i∑jΔrij.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle r_i = i\, \frac{1}{2}\sum_{j+k=i}\Delta r_{jk} - i\, \sum_j \Delta r_{ij} . $$\end{document}

These rates conserve the total volume fraction ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}, i.e., ∂tϕtot=∑iri=0\begin{document}$\partial_{t}\phi_{\text{tot}}=\sum_{i}r_{i}=0$\end{document}. The assembly flux between two assemblies of size i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} and j\begin{document}$j$\end{document}, and the combined (i+j)\begin{document}$(i+j)$\end{document} -mer reads(38)Δrij=kij[exp⁡(iμi+jμjkBT)−exp⁡((i+j)μi+jkBT)],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta r_{ij} = k_{ij} \left[ \exp\left(\frac{ i \mu_i + j \mu_j}{ k_\text{B}T} \right) -\exp\left(\frac{(i+j)\mu_{i+j}}{ k_\text{B}T} \right) \right] ,$$\end{document}

and is determined by differences in chemical potential per monomer. We now isolate the logarithmic part in the chemical potential and introduce chemical activities γi\begin{document}$\gamma_{i}$\end{document} via(39)μi=i−1ln⁡(ϕiiγi).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mu_i = i^{-1} \ln \left(\frac{\phi_i}{i} \gamma_i \right) .$$\end{document}

Choosing kij=2k~exp⁡[−[iln⁡γi+jln⁡γj]]\begin{document}$k_{ij}=2\tilde{k}\exp\left[-[i\ln\gamma_{i}+j\ln\gamma_{j}]\right]$\end{document}, we can recast the assembly flux in Equation 37 as(40)Δrij=2k~(ϕiiϕjj−Fijϕi+ji+j),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Delta r_{ij} = 2 \tilde{k} \left(\frac{\phi_{i} }{i} \frac{\phi_j}{j} \, - F_{ij} \frac{\phi_{i+j}}{i+j}\right) ,$$\end{document}

which leads to a finite flux Δrij\begin{document}$\Delta r_{ij}$\end{document} in the limit ϕi≪1\begin{document}$\phi_{i}\ll 1$\end{document}. In the literature, Fij\begin{document}$F_{ij}$\end{document} is known as a fragmentation kernel, and in our case, it reads Fij=exp⁡[(i+j)ln⁡γi+j−iln⁡γi−jln⁡γj]\begin{document}$F_{ij}=\exp\left[(i+j)\ln\gamma_{i+j}-i\ln\gamma_{i}-j\ln\gamma_{j}\right]$\end{document}. For linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) belonging to Class 1, the fragmentation kernel is constant Fij=ϕ~=exp⁡(ΔωkBT−1)\begin{document}$F_{ij}=\tilde{\phi}=\exp\left(\frac{\Delta\omega}{k_{\text{B}}T}-1\right)$\end{document} in agreement with standard polymerisation models (Krapivsky et al., 2010). For linear assemblies (d=1\begin{document}$d=1$\end{document}) belonging to Class 2, Fij=F(ϕtot)=exp⁡(ΔωkBT−1−χ−χ′kBT(1−ϕtot))\begin{document}$F_{ij}=F(\phi_{\text{tot}})=\exp\left(\frac{\Delta\omega}{k_{\text{B}}T}-1- \frac{\chi-\chi^{\prime}}{k_{\text{B}}T}(1-\phi_{\text{tot}})\right)$\end{document}, i.e., the fragmentation kernel is still size independent but now depends on the total monomer volume fraction ϕtot\begin{document}$\phi_{\text{tot}}$\end{document}.Note that by making the kinetic rate coefficients corresponding to associations of small assemblies, i.e., kij\begin{document}$k_{ij}$\end{document} with i,j≪M\begin{document}$i,j\ll M$\end{document}, explicitly dependent on the presence of large assemblies, our framework can be easily generalised to include primary and secondary nucleation (Michaels et al., 2018). Following again (Krapivsky et al., 2010), we can express the time evolution of ϕi(t)\begin{document}$\phi_{i}(t)$\end{document} as follows:(41)ϕi(t)=ϕtot(1−a(t))2a(t)i−1,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \phi_i(t) = \phi_{\rm tot} \left(1-a(t)\right)^2 a(t)^{i-1},$$\end{document}(42)a(t)=1−exp⁡[−(η−1−η)ϕtott]η−1−ηexp⁡[−(η−1−η)ϕtott],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle a(t) = \frac{1-\exp[ -(\eta^{-1} - \eta) \phi_{\rm tot} t ]}{ \eta^{-1} -\eta \exp[ -(\eta^{-1} - \eta) \phi_{\rm tot} t ] } ,$$\end{document}

where η\begin{document}$\eta$\end{document} is the following function of the fragmentation kernel F(ϕtot)\begin{document}$F(\phi_{\text{tot}})$\end{document}:(43)η=1+2ϕtotF−1+4ϕtotF2ϕtotF.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta = \frac{ 1+2 \frac{\phi_\text{tot}}{F} - \sqrt{1+4 \frac{\phi_\text{tot} }{F} }} { 2\frac{\phi_\text{tot} }{F} } .$$\end{document}

sec.title: B Assembly kinetics in phase-separated systems

caption.title: Kinetic trajectory in the multicomponent phase diagram.
caption.p: Illustration of the assembly kinetics at phase equilibrium for systems corresponding to M=3\begin{document}$M=3$\end{document} and initially composed of monomers only.

sec.p: Here, we generalise the assembly kinetics described in the previous section to the case of phase coexistence. To this end, we focus on passive systems that can relax toward thermodynamic equilibrium. Moreover, we restrict ourselves to systems that are at phase equilibrium at any time during the relaxation kinetics toward thermodynamic equilibrium and following the theory originally developed in Bauermann et al., 2022. Chemical kinetics constrained to phase equilibrium is valid if the chemical reaction rates are small compared to diffusion rates. By choosing initial average volume fractions corresponding to two-phase coexistence, we can consider the system volume to be divided into two homogeneous compartments as a result of phase separation. We then study the time evolution of compartment sizes and volume fractions due to chemical reactions, enforcing instantaneous phase equilibrium at all times. To this aim, we start with the variation of particle numbers in compartments I and II:(44)dNiI/IIdt=−JiI/II+RiI/II,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{d{N_{i}}^{\text{I/II}}}{dt} =-J_{i}^{\text{I/II}}+R_{i}^{ \text{I/II}},$$\end{document}

where RiI/II\begin{document}$R_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} are the variations due to chemical reactions and JiI/II\begin{document}$J_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} describes the exchange of assemblies between the two phases. Particle conservation during crossing implies JiI=−JiII\begin{document}$J_{i}^{\text{I}}=-J_{i}^{\text{II}}$\end{document}. Due to volume conservation in the two-phase, we have(45)VI/II=∑i=0MNiI/IIνi.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle V^\text{I/II} = \sum_{i=0}^M N_i^\text{I/II} \nu_i.$$\end{document}

Furthermore, V=VI+VII\begin{document}$V=V^{\text{I}}+V^{\text{II}}$\end{document}. We now introduce volume fractions ϕiI/II=NiI/II/VI/II\begin{document}$\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}={N_{i}^{\text{I/II}}}/{V^{\text{I/II}}}$\end{document} and the rescaled rates jiI/II=νiJii/II/VI/II\begin{document}$j_{i}^{\text{I/II}}=\nu_{i}\,J_{i}^{\text{i/II}}/V^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} and riI/II=νiRiI/II/VI/II\begin{document}$r_{i}^{\text{I/II}}=\nu_{i}\,R_{i}^{\text{I/II}}/V^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document}, leading to(46)dϕiI/IIdt=−jiI/II+riI/II−ϕiI/IIdln⁡VI/IIdt,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{{\rm d}{\phi_{i}}^{\text{I/II}}}{{\rm d}t} =-j_{i}^{\text{I/II}}+r_{i} ^{\text{I/II}}-\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}\,\frac{{\rm d}\, {\ln V}^{\text{I/II}}}{{\rm d}t},$$\end{document}

which correspond to Equation 36 generalised to two-phase coexistence. The rates in both phases riI/II\begin{document}$r_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} are given in Equation 18; Equation 44; Equation 45 can be combined to get (d/dt)VI/II=VI/II∑i=0M(riI/II−jiI/II)\begin{document}$(d/dt)V^{\text{I/II}}=V^{\text{I/II}}\sum_{i=0}^{M}(r_{i}^{\text{I/II}}-j_{i}^ {\text{I/II}})$\end{document}. Using the volume-conserving properties of the rates, ∑i=1MriI/II=0\begin{document}$\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}^{\text{I/II}}=0$\end{document}, we finally obtain(47)dln⁡VI/IIdt=−∑i=0MjiI /II.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{{\rm d}{\ln V}^{\text{I/II}}}{{\rm d}t} =-\sum_{i=0}^{M}j_{i}^{\text{I /II}}.$$\end{document}
Assembly mass conservation at the interface implies(48)jiI=−jiIIVIIVI,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle j_i^\text{I} = - j_i^\text{II} \frac{V^\text{II} }{V^\text{I} } ,$$\end{document}
with the volume dynamics obeying (d/dt)(VI+VII)=0\begin{document}$(d/dt)(V^{\text{I}}+V^{\text{II}})=0$\end{document}.

The currents jiI/II\begin{document}$j_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} enforce that phase equilibrium is satisfied at all times, which can be expressed by taking a time derivative of Equation 7a, Equation 7b:(49a)∑j=1M∂μiI∂ϕjIdϕjIdt=∑j=1M∂μiII∂ϕjIIdϕjIIdt,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{M} \frac{\partial \mu_i^{\rm I}}{\partial \phi_j^{\rm I}} \frac{d \phi_j^{\rm I}}{dt} = \sum_{j=1}^{M} \frac{\partial \mu_i^{\rm II}}{\partial \phi_j^{\rm II}} \frac{d \phi_j^{\rm II}}{dt}, $$\end{document}(49b)∑j=1M∂ΠiI∂ϕjIdϕjIdt=∑j=1M∂ΠiII∂ϕjIIdϕjIIdt,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{M} \frac{\partial \Pi _i^{\rm I}}{\partial \phi_j^{\rm I}} \frac{d \phi_j^{\rm I}}{dt} = \sum_{j=1}^{M} \frac{\partial \Pi_i^{\rm II}}{\partial \phi_j^{\rm II}} \frac{d \phi_j^{\rm II}}{dt}, $$\end{document}

provided that the initial phase volume and volume fractions VI(t=0)\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}(t=0)$\end{document}, and ϕiI/II(t=0)\begin{document}$\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}(t=0)$\end{document} are a solution of Equation 7a, Equation 7b. Once an expression for ∂μi/∂ϕj\begin{document}$\partial{\mu_{i}}/\partial{\phi_{j}}$\end{document} and ∂Π/∂ϕj\begin{document}$\partial{\Pi}/\partial{\phi_{j}}$\end{document} is calculated, we can derive a set of (M+1)\begin{document}$(M+1)$\end{document} equations for jiI\begin{document}$j_{i}^{\text{I}}$\end{document} inserting Equations 46–48 in Equation 49a. These equations are linear and enable us to find an expression for jiI/II\begin{document}$j_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} as a function of ϕiI/II\begin{document}$\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} and VI/V\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}/V$\end{document}. We have finally all the ingredients to characterize the dynamics of the phase volume and volume fractions ϕiI/II(t)\begin{document}$\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}(t)$\end{document} and VI(t)\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}(t)$\end{document}, integrating Equation 46; Equation 47 and provided we can solve the initial phase equilibrium problem to find VI(t=0)/V\begin{document}$V^{\text{I}}(t=0)/V$\end{document}, and ϕiI/II(t=0)\begin{document}$\phi_{i}^{\text{I/II}}(t=0)$\end{document}. This scheme can be used to study the kinetics of a system initially composed of two phases filled by monomers only that relax to its thermodynamic equilibrium. An illustration of such relaxation kinetics is depicted in Appendix 6—figure 1. Note that the currents jiI/II\begin{document}$j_{i}^{\text{I/II}}$\end{document} restrict the trajectories to lie in the binodal manifold at all times.

body.p: The authors present an important theoretical framework that describes the interplay between liquid-liquid phase separation and protein aggregation within a mean-field model. This work will be of high interest to the biophysics and molecular biology communities, as it will help understand and analyse assembly within biomolecular condensates in cells or in-vitro. Major strengths of this convincing work are the consideration of aggregates with various dimensionality and the possibility for protein gelation.
Summary:

The authors combine classical theories of phase separation and self-assembly to establish a framework for explaining the coupling between the two phenomena in the context of protein assemblies and condensates. By starting from a mean-field free energy for monomers and assemblies immersed in solvent and imposing conditions of equilibrium, the authors derive phase diagrams indicating how assemblies partition into different condensed phases as temperature and the total volume fraction of proteins are varied. They find that phase separation can promote assembly within the protein-rich phase, providing a potential mechanism for spatial control of assembly. They extend their theory to account for the possibility of gelation. They also create a theory for the kinetics of self-assembly within phase separated systems, predicting how assembly size distributions change with time within the different phases as well as how the volumes of the different phases change with time.
Review For Revision:

The revised manuscript provides better motivation and physical explanations for the equations, and the authors have addressed references, typos, and other minor technical issues identified in the review. These changes have significantly improved the manuscript.

aff.institution: Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems

body.p: The following is the authors’ response to the original reviews.

disp-quote.p: Summary:

The authors present a mean-field model that describes the interplay between (protein) aggregation and phase separation. Different classes of interaction complexity and aggregate dimensionality are considered, both in calculations concerning (equilibrium) phase behavior and kinetics of assembly formation.
Strengths:

The present work is, although purely theoretical, of high interest to understanding biological processes that occur as a result of a coupling between protein aggregation and phase separation. Of course, such processes are abundant, in the living cell as well as in in-vitro experiments. I appreciate the consideration of aggregates with various dimensionality, as well as the categorization into different ”interaction classes”, together with the mentioning of experimental observations from biology. The model is convincing and underlines the complexity associated with the distribution of proteins across phases and aggregates in the living cell.
Weaknesses:
There are a few minor weaknesses.

This work deals with a very difficult physical problem: relating the assembly of building blocks on a molecular scale to the appearance of large, macroscopic assemblies. This problem is particularly difficult to treat, because of the large number of units involved, and of the complex way in which these units-monomers-interact with each other and with the solvent. In order to make the problem treatable, the authors recur to a number of approximations: Among these, there is the assumption that the system is spatially homogeneous, i.e., its features are the same in all regions of space. In particular, the homogeneity assumption may not hold in biologically relevant systems such as cells, where the behavior close to the cell membrane may strongly differ from the one in the bulk. As a result, this hypothesis calls for a cautious consideration and interpretation of the results of this work. Another notable simplification introduced by the authors is the assumption that the system can only follow two possible behaviors: In the first, each monomer interacts equally with the solvent; no matter the size of the cluster of which it is part. In the second case, monomers in the bulk of a cluster and monomers at the assembly boundary interact with the solvent in a different way. These two cases are considered not only because they simplify the problem, but also because they are inspired by biologically relevant proteins.

With these simplifications, the authors trace the phase diagram of the system, characterizing its phases for different fractions of the volume occupied by the monomers and solvent, and for different values of the temperature. The results qualitatively reproduce some features observed in recent experiments, such as an anomalous distribution of cluster sizes below the system saturation threshold, and the gelation of condensed phases above such threshold.
Summary:

The authors combine classical theories of phase separation and self-assembly to establish a framework for explaining the coupling between the two phenomena in the context of protein assemblies and condensates. By starting from a mean-field free energy for monomers and assemblies immersed in solvent and imposing conditions of equilibrium, the authors derive phase diagrams indicating how assemblies partition into different condensed phases as temperature and the total volume fraction of proteins are varied. They find that phase separation can promote assembly within the protein-rich phase, providing a potential mechanism for spatial control of assembly. They extend their theory to account for the possibility of gelation. They also create a theory for the kinetics of self-assembly within phase separated systems, predicting how assembly size distributions change with time within the different phases as well as how the volumes of the different phases change with time.
Strengths:

The theoretical framework that the authors present is an interesting marriage of classic theories of phase separation and self-assembly. Its simplicity should make it a powerful general tool for understanding the thermodynamics of assembly coupled to phase separation, and it should provide a useful framework for analyzing experiments on assembly within biomolecular condensates.
The key advance over previous work is that the authors now account for how self-assembly can change the boundaries of the phase diagram.

A second interesting point is the explicit theoretical consideration for the possibility that gelation (i.e. self-assembly into a macroscopic aggregate) could account for widely observed solidification of condensates. While this concept has been broadly discussed, to date I have yet to see a rigorous theoretical analysis of the possibility.
The kinetic theory in sections 5 and 6 is also interesting as it extends on previous work by considering the kinetics of phase separation as well as those of self-assembly.
Weaknesses:

A key point the authors make about their theory is that it allows, as opposed to previous research, to study non-dilute limits. It is true that they consider gelation when the 3D assemblies become macroscopic. However, dilute solution theory assumptions seem to be embedded in many aspects of their theory, and it is not always clear where else the non-dilute limits are considered. Is it in the inter-species interaction χij? Why then do they never explore cases for which χij is nonzero in their analysis?

body.p: We explicitly consider that monomers and aggregates are non-dilute with respect to solvent. This is evident in accounting for the mixing entropy of all components, including the solvent. Moreover, we account for interactions among the monomers and the different aggregates with the solvent. We consider the case where each monomeric unit, independent in aggregate it is part of, interacts the same way with the solvent. Please note that this case corresponds to a non-dilute scenario where interactions indeed drive phase separation.

disp-quote.p: The connection between this theory and biological systems is described in the introduction but lost along the main text. It would be very helpful to point out, for instance, that the presence of phase separation might induce aggregation of proteins. This point is described formally at the end of Section 3, but a more qualitative connection to biological systems would be very useful here.

body.p: We thank the referee for the useful comment, we now mention this in the introduction (line 80) and point out the biological relevance of assembly formation and localization via the presence of phase separation (lines 268 and 283).

disp-quote.p: Building on the previous point, it would be helpful to give an intuitive sense of where the equations derived in the Appendices and presented in the main text come from and to spell out clear physical interpretations of the results. For example, it would be helpful to point out that Eq. 4 is a form of the law of mass action, familiar from introductory chemistry. It would be useful to better explain how the current work extends on existing previous work from these authors as well as others. Along these lines, closely related work by W. Jacobs and B. Rogers [O. Hedge et al. 2023, https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06134; T. Li et al. 2023, https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13198] should be cited in the introduction. The results discussed in the first paragraph of Section 3 on assembly size distributions in a homogeneous system are well-known from classic theories of self-assembly. This should be acknowledged and appropriate references should be added; see for instance, Rev. Mod. Phys. 93, 025008 and Statistical Thermodynamics Of Surfaces, Interfaces, And Membranes by Sam Safran. Equation 14 for the kinetic of volume fractions is given with reference to Bauermann et al. 2022, but it should be accompanied by a better intuitive interpretation of its terms in the main text. In particular, how should one understand the third term in this equation? Why does the change in volume impact the change of volume fraction in this way?

body.p: We thank the referee for the suggestions. We have included the missing references, with a particular emphasis on DNA nanostars that inhibit phase separation in DNA liquids in the definition of class II. We added intuitive explanations of the main equations, such as Eqs. (4),(8),(14), (17), and (18). Notice that, according to Mysels, Karol J., J. Chem. Educ., 33, 178 (1956) (https://pubs-acs-org.sire.ub.edu/doi/epdf/10.1021/ed033p178) we refer to (18) as the law of mass action.

disp-quote.p: The discussion in the last paragraph of Section 6 should be clarified. How can the total amount of protein in both phases decrease? This would necessarily violate either mass or volume conservation. Also, the discussion of why the volume is non-monotonic in time is not clear.

body.p: A decrease in the total amount of protein in both phases does not violate mass conservation, if the volume of the phases varies accordingly. In particular, the volume of the denser phase should grow. This given, in the case presented the total protein amount in the dense phase decreases, while in the dilute phase increases. For this reason, we revised the paragraph and now explain the results in more detail (see lines starting from 407). The nonmonotonic volume change is indeed a puzzling finding that, as we now state in the manuscript, requires further investigation. Given the lack of analytical approaches available to tackle the complex kinetics in the presence of coexisting phases, we believe that this analysis goes beyond the scope of the present paper.

disp-quote.p: Line 96: I feel a mentioning/definition/explanation and perhaps some discussion on the parameter M (limiting aggregate size) would have been in place in the introduction of Equation (1). Furthermore, in the usual interpretation, Flory interaction parameters (symbolized χ) are dimensionless, as, classically, they represent an exchange energy (normalized by kT), defined on a monomeric basis. Here they seem to carry the dimension of energy.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for the observation. We have included a brief comment on M and mentioned that we use χ parameters that carry the dimension of energy such that, varying kBT, we scale at the same time the term containing interaction propensities (χ) and the one containing internal energies (_e_int). See the comment on line 127

disp-quote.p: Line 150: The choice of ρi = i physically implies that a single protein is assumed to have the same as a solvent molecule. This may be a bit of a stretch. This assumption leads to an overestimation of the translational entropy of the aggregates (first term in Equation (1)). Acknowledging that _ρ_1 >> ρs would give a pronounced desymmetrization of the phase diagram (I suspect).

body.p: Indeed, in the case of monomers only, the assumption leads to a symmetric phase diagram which may be unrealistic. Once assemblies form, however, the phase diagram becomes asymmetric and for this reason we decided to assume ρi = i, simplifying the theoretical analysis. We have added a clarifying sentence in the manuscript, see line 163

disp-quote.p: Furthermore, the pictures in Figure 1a-c suggest the presence of a disordered residue, the degree of swelling of which might affect binding strength (see for instance: https://doi.org/10.3389/fnmol.2022.962526).

body.p: We added a comment on the possible coupling between internal free energies and interaction propensities, such as the swelling mechanism that affects binding sites, and included the reference above (line 215).

disp-quote.p: Line 154-156: It’s unclear what is meant with ”an internal bond that keeps each assembly together”. How should this be interpreted on an intuitive physical level?

body.p: We apologise for being unclear. We meant the internal bonds that lead to the formation of assemblies. We have now rephrased this sentence in the main text (lines starting from 169).

disp-quote.p: Line 254: The fact that ϕsg is defined below does not mean it does not fall out of the air here. The same holds for the consideration of the limit M →∞. Ideally, the main text should stand on its own, in particular with respect to physical intuitiveness, as well as the necessity and interest of discussion topics. Technical details, derivations and additional information can be in an appendix.

body.p: We agree with the referee and added some physical insights about the limit. We now also state clearly in the main text (line 298) that _ϕ_sg is affected by temperature and the free energy of internal bonds.

disp-quote.p: Line 257: ”Since we do not explicitly include the solvent in assembly formation we will consider the gel as a phase without solvent and thus ϕtot = 1”. I’m not sure if I can agree with this. I would say, a gel, certainly in biological context, almost per definition contains a large fraction of solvent, i.e. here water. The situation ”ϕtot = 1” would rather be a solid precipitate. Is gelation properly captured by this model?

body.p: We thank the referee for this very relevant observation. We now state in the main text that the model predicts a macroscopic assembly which we call ’the gel phase’, in agreement with previous literature. Then, to clarify, we added the sentence ”Please note that, since we do not explicitly include the solvent in assembly formation (see reaction scheme in Fig.1a), in our model the gel corresponds to a phase without solvent, _ϕ_tot = 1. To account for biological gels that can be rich in water, our theory can be straightforwardly extended by incorporating the solvent into the reaction scheme.”, see main text line 300.

disp-quote.p: Line 268: Shouldn’t ”solvent” be ”solution”? If fsol is given by Equation (1), surely not only the solvent is considered.

body.p: Indeed, this is a typo, and we now use the term ’solution’ instead of ’solvent.’

disp-quote.p: Line 273: At this stage, the only information provided in the main text is that ω∞ is ”a constant that does not affect chemical nor phase equilibrium, except in the limit M →∞” (see lines 153-154). This is a little bit too abstract for me. Again, the main text should stand on its own, meaning the reader should not have to rely on an appendix to at least have an intuitive physical understanding of any modeling or input parameter discussed in the main text.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for pointing this out. We now comment on the physical interpretation of ω∞ in the main text, see lines from 320 on.

disp-quote.p: Figure 4. k~\begin{document}$\tilde{k}$\end{document} appears in Equation (39) but it is not defined.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for pointing this out. We have reshaped appendix 6A, making use of chemical activities and clarified the origin of the rate k~\begin{document}$\tilde{k}$\end{document}.

disp-quote.p: Line 317. I don’t fully understand the intention of the remark on the model being adaptable for ”primary and secondary nucleation”. How/in what way is this different from association and dissociation? For instance, classical nucleation theory is based on association and dissociation of monomeric units to and from clusters.

body.p: We agree that the kinetic rate coefficients kij (appearing in the association and dissociation rates ∆rij, Eq. 17) in our manuscript already depend on assembly length, see Appendix 6 B, where we now clarified their definition. Please note that, however, that secondary nucleation is a special kind of association, for which the kinetic rate coefficients corresponding to associations of small assemblies, i.e. kij with_i,j_ ≪ M, explicitly depend on the presence of large assemblies with sizes l ≫ 1. In our manuscript, we have not accounted for such a dependence. We now make this aspect clear in the manuscript, see Appendix 6 B.

disp-quote.p: Line 321. Why is ∆rij called the ”monomer exchange rate”? In line 318 the same parameter is defined as the ”reaction rate for the formation of a (i+j)-mer”. Why should these be the same?

body.p: We thank the reviewer for spotting this typo.

disp-quote.p: Line 323. Why do these calculations use M = 15?

body.p: The exploration of a 15-dimensional phase space is already numerically challenging. We are currently working on a generalization of the numerical scheme to work with larger values of M but, to discuss the fundamental physical principles, we kept M = 15.

disp-quote.p: The manuscript presents several issues, on both the scientific and presentational level, which need to be carefully addressed. Please find below a list of the points that need to be addressed by the authors, divided into major and minor points. Major issues:

• A general, major concern about the results in the paper is the homogeneity assumption. I do understand that repeating the whole analysis presented in the manuscript by allowing for spatial inhomogeneities partially goes beyond the scope of this paper. However, the authors should at least discuss how such inhomogeneities may alter the results in a qualitative way, and treat explicitly the presence of inhomogeneity in one prototypical case treated in the manuscript. Namely, what happens if the volume fractions and relative molecular volumes in the free energy (1) depend on space, e.g., ϕi → ϕi(x)?

body.p: We would like to stress that, in the present paper, we do account for spatial inhomogeneities. Indeed, in the case of phase separation, we consider systems which are divided into two phases, characterized by different values of the assemblies’ volume fractions ϕi. We do, however, consider the system to be homogeneous inside the phases, implying a jump in the value of the volume fraction at the interface between the two phases. In this sense, the analysis we carry out is valid in the thermodynamic limit, where gradients of the volume fractions ϕi(x) within the phases, can be neglected. On the other hand, considering the full spatial problem, i.e. solving the equations for M = 15 spatially varying fields, would be numerically extremely challenging.

disp-quote.p: • The authors’ results relate molecular assembly- a phenomenon at the molecular scale-to phase separation-a mesoscopic or macroscopic phenomenon. The authors should stress the conceptual importance of this connection between scales, and present their results from the perspective of a multi-scale model.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for pointing this out. We now emphasize the multi-scale feature of our model in the introduction (line 80).

disp-quote.p: • Starting from Section 1, the reader is not well guided through the sections that follow. The authors should provide an outline of the line of though that they are going to follow in the following sections, and logically connect each section to the next one with a short paragraph at the end of each section. This paragraph should resume what has been addressed in the current section, and the connection with the topic that will be addressed in the next one.

body.p: We agree with the reviewer and have added a transitioning sentence at the end of each paragraph.

disp-quote.p: • ’We focus on linear assemblies (d = 1)’: Given the striking differences of the results between d = 1 and d > 1 shown above, the authors should discuss what happens for d > 1 as well.

• ’In figure Fig. 5a, we show the initial and final equilibrium binodals (black and coloured curve, respectively), for the case of linear assemblies (d = 1) belonging to class 1’: Again, show what happens for d > 1.

body.p: We agree with the reviewer, the kinetics in d > 1 would be definitely interesting. However, in this case, one assembly can become macroscopic (i.e. M must be set to ∞). This requires some substantial modification in the kinetic scheme, like introducing an absorbing boundary condition for monomers ’sucked in’ the gel. We prefer to leave this for future work, and now state it explicitly in the manuscript (line 383).

disp-quote.p: • ’This difference arises because, within class 2, monomers in the bulk of an assembly have reduced interaction propensity with respect to the boundary ones. As a consequence, the formation of large clusters shifts the onset of phase separation to higher ϕtot values.’: To prove this argument, the authors should show Fig. 2g and h for d > 1. In fact, by varying d, the effect of the boundary vs. bulk also varies.

body.p: We prefer to discuss the thermodynamics of d > 1 in section 4 on gelation. There we present only a single phase diagram so as not to blow up the discussion on equilibrium too much.

disp-quote.p: • ’referring for simplicity to systems belonging to Class 1’: The authors should do the same analysis for Class 2.

body.p: We agree with the reviewer. However, again not to blow up the discussion on equilibrium, we leave it for future work.

disp-quote.p: • ’other, implying that the corresponding Flory-Huggins parameter χij vanishes’: Why?

body.p: The explanation based on a lattice model is reported in Appendix 2, and is now more clearly referenced (line 185).

disp-quote.p: Minor issues:

• Eq. (10): Here the authors should explain in the main text, possibly in a simple and intuitive way, why the number of monomers i and the space dimension d enter the righthand side of this equation in this particular way.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for pointing this out. We added the physical origin of the scaling with dimension in Eq. (10) and in Eq. (8), as pointed out by reviewer 3.

disp-quote.p: • ’The second and fifth terms of fsol characterize the internal free energies’: What do you mean by ’characterize the internal free energies’? Please clarify.

body.p: As we now state more clearly (lines 114-120), these two contributions include the internal free energies _ω_s and ωi, stemming from the free energy of internal bonds that lead to assembly formation.

disp-quote.p: • ’depend on the scaling form of the’: Scaling with respect to what ? Please clarify.

body.p: We have now clarified that the scaling is with respect to the assembly size i.

disp-quote.p: • Figure 2 is way too dense: it should be split into two figures, and the legend of each of the two figures should be expanded to properly guide the reader to understand the figures.

body.p: We understand the reviewer’s point of view. To avoid altering the present flow, we decided not to split the figure, but we have included shaded boxes to better guide the reader.

disp-quote.p: • ’this is a consequence of the gelation transition’: Please clarify
• ’and this limitation can be dealt with by introducing explicitly the infinite-sized gel in the free energy’: Why? Please clarify.

body.p: We have now rephrased these sentences, hopefully in a clearer way. We now state: ’We know that this divergence is physical, and is caused by the gelation transition. This limitation can be dealt with by introducing explicitly a term in the free energy that accounts for an infinite-sized assembly (the gel)’, see lines 320-322.

disp-quote.p: • Figure 4: Add plots of panels d, e, h and i with log scale on the y axis to make explicit an eventual exponential behavior, and revise the text accordingly

body.p: Not to further complicate Figure 4, we preferred to display the logarithmic plots of the equilibrium distribution in the appendix, see Figure A3-1.

disp-quote.p: • ’... an equilibrium distribution which monotonously decreases with assembly size’: It is not the distributions that decreases but the cluster volume fraction, please rephrase.

body.p: We thank the reviewer for pointing this out and have now rephrased this sentence (line 394).

disp-quote.p: I could not obtain the exact form of Eq 29 in App 3, can the authors elaborate on this calculation. App 3: What does it mean binodal agrees well with ϕsg? And doesn’t ϕsg depend on temperature through phi tilde? What temperature is this result for?

body.p: We apologise for the unclear explanation. We now state in detail that Eq. (29) is obtained by plugging the expression of ϕi given in Eq. (24) into Eq. (1), in the main text. The dependence of ϕ1 on ϕtot is expressed in Eq. (26), and we have omitted linear terms in ϕtot, since they do not affect phase equilibrium (see lines 802-809). Moreover, ϕsg depends indeed on kBT. We refer to the comparison between the full curve ϕsg in the kBT−ϕtot plane, and the branch of the binodal between the triple point (indicated now with a cross) and ϕtot = 1. The two curves are close, as expected since both correspond to the boundary between homogeneous mixtures and the gel state, obtained with different methods.

disp-quote.p: The references to Figures in the appendices are confusing. Please make it clear whether Figures in the main text or the appendices are being referenced. On a related note, the Appendix figures seem to be placed in appendices whose text describes something else - Appendix 2, Figure 1 should be moved to Appendix 3; Appendix 3, Figure 1 should be moved to Appendix 4; etc.

body.p: We revised the appendix, corrected the figure positions and clarified their references.
